subject: Re: [junit] Re: Problems running JUnit
msgSnippet: ... It depends. In what package is your X class defined? If it s the default package, then no import statement is needed. If X is defined in, say, package
messageBody:
On 10/23/06, Magnus <t703093@...> wrote:
> so I have to write:
> import X;
>
> in the top of the TestX.java ?

It depends. In what package is your "X" class defined? If it's the
default package, then no import statement is needed. If X is defined
in, say, package "com.acme" then you need to "import com.acme.X;".

There's probably some Java tutorial out there in the internet that
tells you more about the magic of import statements.

Lasse
